messageBody:
Hi,

Thanks for the clear responses. What i see is that a theory is a
(parametrized) test inside out; you don't specify what will work but you
leave out what should not be tested (iow assumptions by leaving out the data
for these cases).

I do indeed like the syntax of theories better than how parameterized tests
should be expressed. Especially using custom annotations @Between
(http://popper.tigris.org/tutorial.html) are very powerful, also to supply
test data for parametrized tests.

Anyway the difference between them is clear, perhaps a more expressive
technique for specifying parameter values for a parameterized test will make
it into Junit...

Tx.,

Raphael



Charlie Poole-2 wrote:
>
> Hi David,
>
>> [+CC: Charlie Poole, who might be interested in the example...]
>
> Thanks - but I'm here too. :-)
>
>> Joakim is correct. A theory promises that correct code will
>> pass the theory for any parameters you pass in:
>>
>> @Theory public void additionIsCommutative(int x, int y) {
>> assertEquals(x + y, y + x);
>> }
>>
>> A "Parameterized test" is what I like to call an "answer
>> key". It can be applied to some different parameters, but
>> you have to look at the key to know which are correct. If we
>> converted the Parameterized Runner to behave more like
>> theories, it might look like (totally making this up):
>>
>> // Read top to bottom
>> @Answers("a") public int[] = {3, 4, 5}
>> @Answers("b") public int[] = {4, 3, 12}
>> @Answers("c") public int[] = {5, 5, 13}
>>
>> @AnswerKey public void pythogoreanTheorem(int a, int b, int c) {
>> assertEquals(c, hypoteneuse(a, b));
>> }>
>> The Theories interface currently looks different than the
>> Parameterized interface because experience with the
>> Parameterized Runner made me dissatisfied with the interface.
>
> I think NUnit has some fairly nice syntax for parameterized tests,
> primarily because other people experimented with it first and
> I learned from their experience. So, as payback, here are a few
> alternatives we currently (2.5 Alpha) support...
>
> [Test]
> public void pythogoreanTheorem(
> [Values(3,4,5)] int a,
> [Values(4,3,12)] int b,
> [Values(5,5,13)] int c)
> {
> Assert.AreEqual(c, hypoteneuse(a, b));
> }
>
> OR
>
> [TestCase(3,4,5)]
> [TestCase(4,3,5)]
> [TestCase(4,12,13)]
> public void pythogoreanTheorem(int a, int b, int c)
> {
> Assert.AreEqual(c, hypoteneuse(a, b));
> }
>
> OR
>
> [TestCase(3,4, Returns=5)]
> [TestCase(4,3, Returns=5)]
> [TestCase(4,12, Returns=13)]
> public void pythogoreanTheorem(int a, int b)
> {
> return hypoteneuse(a, b);
> }
>
> For this particular test, I have a liking for the
> last format. Of course, I'm not sure which of these
> could be implemented with Java attributes, but I'll
> leave that for somebody else to figure out. :-)
>
> Charlie
>
>
>
>
